content:
....
Attachment_III-B Audit Report No. A-1711
C3-62-0742
March 10, 1962
Mr. R. L. Hirshberg Program Officer AID Mission to China Taipei
Subject: Project-type & Non-pro ject-type Excess Property
Dear Mr. Hirshberg:
Pursuant to your letter MC-2747 dated February 20, 1962 in which you expressed concern over the storage conditions and disposal of the subject excess properties and urged undertaking of remedial measures. We wish to furnish you the following explanations:
I. Requests for machine tools from some Aresenals and other MND production facilities were acknowledged by CUSA with conditions that requirement and end-use justifications be furnished and budget of funding assured within a week. Since three weeks have elapsed, we have written MND declining their request for reservations.
II. On the storage of Project-type excess equipment, immediate contact has been made with BES for improvement. They explained that since they have no godowns for storage purpose, all arrived equipment were placed in open yard. However, enough tarpaulins are being used for covering up. Frequent inspections of the equipment by interested parties are the principal reason for the unsatisfactory storage conditions to which more attention will be paid from now on, they added.
III. Under Project No. 99-471, all excess equipment delivered upon request s have been duly allocated and utilized. However, you will recall that during a period about one year ago, sizable quantities of excess equipment which had not been requested were shipped from USA and effort had constantly been made to utilize these unexpected arrivals to the best advantage. Major portion has thus been allocated or sold though there is still apportion including conveyors, crakshaft grinders and others which, on account of lack of requirements or being in poor condition, remains in BES yard waiting to be disposed of.
IV. For the excess machineries under Non-pro ject type recently arrived, about one third has either been allocated to Government enterprises or auctioned to private industries. It is expected that the rest will be disposed of in a reasonably short time.
A report on the status of Excess Property arrivals and disposal as of February 15, 1962 has been forwarded to you and further reports will be forwarded monthly for your reference.
Sincerely yours,
C. C. Chang Acting Secretary General
國史饭 Academia Historica
85

Audit Report No. A-1711
March 10, 1962
Mr. R. L. Hirshberg
Program Officer
AID Mission to China
Taipei
Subject: Project-type & Non-pro ject-type
Excess Property
Dear Mr. Hirshberg:
Pursuant to your letter MC-2747 dated February 20, 1962 in which you
expressed concern over the storage conditions and disposal of the
subject excess properties and urged undertaking of remedial measures.
We wish to furnish you the following explanations:
I. Requests for machine tools from some Aresenals and other MND
production facilities were acknowledged by CUSA with conditions that
requirement and end-use justifications be furnished and budget of
funding assured within a week. Since three weeks have elapsed, we have
written MND declining their request for reservations.
II. On the storage of Project-type excess equipment, immediate contact
has been made with BES for improvement. They explained that since
they have no godowns for storage purpose, all arrived equipment were
placed in open yard. However, enough tarpaulins are being used for
covering up. Frequent inspections of the equipment by interested
parties are the principal reason for the unsatisfactory storage
conditions to which more attention will be paid from now on, they added.
III. Under Project No. 99-471, all excess equipment delivered upon
request s have been duly allocated and utilized. However, you will
recall that during a period about one year ago, sizable quantities of
excess equipment which had not been requested were shipped from USA and
effort had constantly been made to utilize these unexpected arrivals to
the best advantage. Major portion has thus been allocated or sold
though there is still apportion including conveyors, crakshaft grinders
and others which, on account of lack of requirements or being in poor
condition, remains in BES yard waiting to be disposed of.
IV. For the excess machineries under Non-pro ject type recently arrived,
about one third has either been allocated to Government enterprises or
auctioned to private industries. It is expected that the rest will be
disposed of in a reasonably short time.
A report on the status of Excess Property arrivals and disposal as of
February 15, 1962 has been forwarded to you and further reports will
be forwarded monthly for your reference.
Sincerely yours,
C. C. Chang
Acting Secretary General

paragraphs.content: Mr. R. L. Hirshberg Program Officer AID Mission to China Taipei
Subject: Project-type & Non-pro ject-type Excess Property

Pursuant to your letter MC-2747 dated February 20, 1962 in which you expressed concern over the storage conditions and disposal of the subject excess properties and urged undertaking of remedial measures. We wish to furnish you the following explanations:

I. Requests for machine tools from some Aresenals and other MND production facilities were acknowledged by CUSA with conditions that requirement and end-use justifications be furnished and budget of funding assured within a week. Since three weeks have elapsed, we have written MND declining their request for reservations.

II. On the storage of Project-type excess equipment, immediate contact has been made with BES for improvement. They explained that since they have no godowns for storage purpose, all arrived equipment were placed in open yard. However, enough tarpaulins are being used for covering up. Frequent inspections of the equipment by interested parties are the principal reason for the unsatisfactory storage conditions to which more attention will be paid from now on, they added.

III. Under Project No. 99-471, all excess equipment delivered upon request s have been duly allocated and utilized. However, you will recall that during a period about one year ago, sizable quantities of excess equipment which had not been requested were shipped from USA and effort had constantly been made to utilize these unexpected arrivals to the best advantage. Major portion has thus been allocated or sold though there is still apportion including conveyors, crakshaft grinders and others which, on account of lack of requirements or being in poor condition, remains in BES yard waiting to be disposed of.

IV. For the excess machineries under Non-pro ject type recently arrived, about one third has either been allocated to Government enterprises or auctioned to private industries. It is expected that the rest will be disposed of in a reasonably short time.
A report on the status of Excess Property arrivals and disposal as of February 15, 1962 has been forwarded to you and further reports will be forwarded monthly for your reference.
C. C. Chang Acting Secretary General
